* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for... Eastern Powell County in east central Kentucky... Morgan County in southeastern Kentucky... Southeastern Bath County in east central Kentucky... East central Estill County in east central Kentucky... Menifee County in east central Kentucky... North central Breathitt County in southeastern Kentucky... Wolfe County in southeastern Kentucky... Elliott County in east central Kentucky...

entry.title: Flood Watch issued April 2 at 10:00AM EDT until April 3 at 2:00AM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Portions of western Maryland, including the following areas, Central and Eastern Allegany, Extreme Western Allegany and Garrett, western Virginia, including the following areas, Eastern Highland and Western Highland, and eastern West Virginia, including the following areas, Eastern Grant, Eastern Mineral, Eastern Pendleton, Western Grant, Western Mineral and Western Pendleton.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Multiple rounds of showers and thunderstorms are expected across the Appalachian region through this evening. Total rainfall of two to four inches of rain are likely with locally higher amounts up to five inches possible over multiple days. This could cause flooding of small streams and creeks. - Please visit www.weather.gov/safety/flood for flood safety and preparedness information
entry.cap:areaDesc: Garrett; Extreme Western Allegany; Central and Eastern Allegany; Western Highland; Eastern Highland; Western Grant; Eastern Grant; Western Mineral; Eastern Mineral; Western Pendleton; Eastern Pendleton

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued April 2 at 9:59AM EDT until April 2 at 1:15PM EDT by NWS Indianapolis IN
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Portions of central, south central, and southeast Indiana, including the following counties, in central Indiana, Bartholomew and Decatur. In south central Indiana, Brown, Jackson, Lawrence and Monroe. In southeast Indiana, Jennings.
* WHEN...Until 115 PM EDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 956 AM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms earlier this morning. Minor flooding is ongoing in the advisory area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain fell, with some upstream locations seeing over 3 inches. - Area creeks and streams are still rising from earlier rainfall. Additional heavy rainfall this afternoon could bring additional flooding to lowland areas. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Bloomington, Columbus, Seymour, Bedford, Greensburg, North Vernon, Brownstown, Nashville, Vernon, Adams, Edinburgh, Mitchell, Hope, Crothersville, Milford, Westport, Princes Lakes, Oolitic, Morgantown and Medora. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Bartholomew, IN; Brown, IN; Decatur, IN; Jackson, IN; Jennings, IN; Lawrence, IN; Monroe, IN

entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Portions of central, east central, south central, southeast, southwest, and west central Indiana, including the following counties, in central Indiana, Bartholomew, Decatur, Hancock, Hendricks, Johnson, Marion, Morgan, Rush and Shelby. In west central Indiana, Clay, Owen, Parke, Putnam, Vermillion and Vigo.
* WHEN...Until 8 PM EDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Rainfall amounts between 1 and 3 inches were common across portions of central Indiana last night and this morning. Additional rainfall is expected this afternoon which may result in additional flooding. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Watch issued April 2 at 8:59AM CDT until April 4 at 1:00AM CDT by NWS Chicago IL
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Chicago IL has issued a Flood Watch for the following rivers in Indiana...Illinois...
Iroquois River at Rensselaer affecting Jasper County.
Iroquois River at Iroquois affecting Newton and Iroquois Counties.
* WHAT...Flooding is possible.
* WHERE...Iroquois River from near Rensselaer downstream to near I-65 east of Foresman, including the Rensselaer gauge.
* WHEN...From this evening to early Thursday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 10.0 feet, Water overtops low-lying banks near Rensselaer. At 12.0 feet, Low-lying agricultural land inundated. Parking lots threatened at Lairds Landing.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 AM CDT Tuesday the stage was 9.8 feet. - Forecast...The river will continue to rise today and tonight and may near flood stage tomorrow. - Flood stage is 12.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 2 at 9:58AM EDT until April 2 at 4:00PM EDT by NWS Pittsburgh PA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall is occurring.
* WHERE...Portions of Pennsylvania, including the following counties, west central Allegheny, southern Beaver, Greene and Washington and the northern panhandle of West Virginia, including the following counties, Brooke, Hancock and Ohio.
* WHEN...Until 400 PM EDT Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Numerous roads remain closed due to flooding. Streams continue to rise due to excess runoff from earlier rainfall.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 956 AM EDT, local law enforcement reported flooding in the warned area. Flooding is already occurring. Between 1.5 and 2.5 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches is expected through this evening, with locally higher amounts possible. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Moon Township, Weirton, Washington, Franklin Park, East Liverpool, Aliquippa, Canonsburg, Waynesburg, Avella, Economy, Ambridge, Baden, Ohioville, Harmony Township, Wolfdale, McGovern, Midland, Imperial, East Washington and Industry. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 2 at 9:58AM EDT until April 3 at 2:36AM EDT by NWS Wilmington OH
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Wilmington has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers...
Mad River near Springfield.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Mad River near Springfield.
* WHEN...Until early Wednesday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 11.0 feet, West 1st Street in Springfield Township floods, including the Forest Lake Fishing and Campround area, with water approaching some businesses along West 1st Street. Spangler Road downstream of Springfield also floods. Flood waters approach several homes to the southwest of Springfield. In addition, the Mad River experiences widespread flooding in Champaign County near the river.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:30 AM EDT Tuesday the stage was 7.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late this morning to a crest of 10.7 feet this afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage this evening. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 2 at 5:33AM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
Bands of moderate to heavy snow showers have developed across the western Kenai Peninsula, Matanuska Valley and Anchorage area this evening. These showers will be capable of producing brief periods of reduced visibility and intense snowfall rates up to an inch an hour at times, with some locations potentially seeing snowfall accumulation between 1 and 4 inches through early Tuesday morning.
Snow showers will gradually diminish by Tuesday morning. However, temperatures will cool to well below freezing as colder air filters into the region. This coupled with the new snowfall could lead to difficult and icy travel conditions for the morning commute.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Anchorage; Matanuska Valley; Western Kenai Peninsula

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 2 at 5:23AM PDT by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* A strong cold front will move through the Sierra and western NV late Wednesday through Thursday and bring gusty winds, much colder temperatures and chances for snow showers.
* Gusty southwest winds will develop Wednesday afternoon north of Highway 50 and shift to the Eastern Sierra of Mono and Mineral counties overnight into Thursday morning. This will impact outdoor activities, produce bumpy airplane rides and cause gusty cross winds for high-profile vehicles, especially along Highway 395 and I-580.
* Snow showers will increase in northeast CA and the Sierra Wednesday and spread across the region Wednesday night through Friday. Several inches of accumulating snow will bring periods of slick and snow covered roads to the Sierra and foothills, especially during the nighttime hours. Prepare for possible delays if your plans include travel through the Sierra.
* Unusually cold air will settle into the area for early April with daytime temperatures 15-20 degrees below normal Thursday and Friday and only warming slightly over the weekend. Hard freezes are almost a certainty each night, even for lower western NV valleys beginning Thursday night. Be ready to protect sensitive plants and wrap exposed irrigation systems.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Surprise Valley California; Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties; Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Mono; Mineral and Southern Lyon Counties; Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Greater Reno-Carson City-Minden Area; Western Nevada Basin and Range including Pyramid Lake; Northern Washoe County

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 2 at 2:50AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A strong storm moving north into the Chukchi Sea on Wednesday will bring water levels up 2 to 3 feet along the coast from the starting Wednesday night. This will cause water to move on top of the ice near the coast in some areas. This could cause trails that cross ice near the coast to become inundated. This event will be similar what happened March 20, 2024.
Winter Storm Warnings, Watches and Advisories have been issued for many of these areas and are available on the Internet at weather.gov/afg.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kivalina and Red Dog Dock; Lower Kobuk Valley; Baldwin Peninsula; Northern Seward Peninsula; Shishmaref

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 2 at 2:50AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A strong storm moving north across the Bering Sea on Tuesday and Wednesday will bring water levels up 3 to 4 feet along the coast from the Bering Strait south on Wednesday and Thursday. This will cause water to move on top of the ice near the coast in some areas. This could cause trails that cross ice near the coast to become inundated. Ice could push onto the beach along south facing coast lines. This event will be similar what happened March 20, 2024.
Winter Storm Warnings, Watches and Advisories have been issued for most of these areas and are available on the Internet at weather.gov/afg.

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued April 2 at 5:16AM AST until April 2 at 6:00PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Hazardous swimming and life-threatening rip current conditions due to breaking waves up to 9 feet.
* WHERE...Beaches along the northern coastline of Puerto Rico from Aguadilla to Fajardo and Culebra.
* WHEN...Through this afternoon.

entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Pittsburgh PA has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Ohio...

* WHEN...From this afternoon to early Friday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 5.0 feet, Stillwater Creek comes out of its banks in several locations resulting in overflowing in poor drainage areas. Minor flooding of low lying areas begins. At 6.5 feet, Flood waters of Stillwater Creek will reach the intersection of East 12th Street and North Main Street in Uhrichsville and approach Newport Street. Little Stillwater Creek will flood most of Phac Park along with portions of Wilson Road in Dennison. At 7.9 feet, Numerous low land areas are flooded. Stillwater Creek begins to flood portions of Newport Street in Uhrichsville. Homes along Park Drive begin to flood. Sections of Wilson Road near Phac Park are flooded. At 8.3 feet, Flood waters reach Newport Avenue in Uhrichsville as well as East 12th Street and North Main Street half way to East 11th Street. Phac Park along Little Stillwater Creek in Dennison is flooded. At 10.0 feet, Stillwater Creek comes out of its banks in several locations resulting in overflowing in poor drainage areas. Minor flooding of low lying areas begins. At 11.5 feet, Flood waters of Stillwater Creek will reach the intersection of East 12th Street and North Main Street in Uhrichsville and approach Newport Street. Little Stillwater Creek will flood most of Phac Park along with portions of Wilson Road in Dennison.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 4:00 AM EDT Tuesday the stage was 9.1 feet. - Bankfull stage is 7.6 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage this afternoon to a crest of 11.5 feet early tomorrow afternoon. entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued April 2 at 3:55AM CDT until April 3 at 7:00AM CDT by NWS La Crosse WI
entry.summary:
......Heavy Wet Snow and Strong Winds Impacting Travel Overnight Into The Wednesday Morning Commute......
.Bands of Heavy Snow and Strong Winds move through central Wisconsin this evening and through the overnight. An initial wintry mix of rain and snow this afternoon will result in slippery, slushy travel conditions. A switch to snow this evening will accumulate on roadways with near a half inch per hour snowfall rates. Rapid reductions in visibilities are also likely within these snow bands. Overall accumulations of 2 to 6 inches are expected into Wednesday morning with narrow corridors of higher amounts possible.
Increased winds of 35 to 45 miles per hour overnight will further travel impacts from blowing snow. Travel conditions can quickly deteriorate from rapid reductions in visibilities.
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 2 to 6 inches. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph.
* WHERE...Portions of central, north central, southwest and west central Wisconsin.
* WHEN...From 4 PM this afternoon to 7 AM CDT Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening commute.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 1 at 10:32PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
Bands of moderate to heavy snow showers have developed across the western Kenai Peninsula, Matanuska Valley and Anchorage area this evening. These showers will be capable of producing brief periods of reduced visibility and intense snowfall rates up to an inch an hour at times, with some locations potentially seeing snowfall accumulation between 1 and 4 inches through early Tuesday morning.
Snow showers will gradually diminish by Tuesday morning. However, temperatures will cool to well below freezing as colder air filters into the region. This coupled with the new snowfall could lead to difficult and icy travel conditions for the morning commute.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Anchorage; Matanuska Valley; Western Kenai Peninsula

cap:parameter.value: AREAS OF MODERATE TO HEAVY SNOW SHOWERS TO PERSIST OVERNIGHT INTO TUESDAY MORNING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 1 at 4:37PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A strong storm moving north into the Chukchi Sea on Wednesday will bring water levels up 2 to 3 feet along the coast from the starting Wednesday night. This will cause water to move on top of the ice near the coast in some areas. This could cause trails that cross ice near the coast to become inundated. This event will be similar what happened March 20, 2024.
Winter Storm Warnings, Watches and Advisories have been issued for many of these areas and are available on the Internet at weather.gov/afg.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kivalina and Red Dog Dock; Lower Kobuk Valley; Baldwin Peninsula; Northern Seward Peninsula; Shishmaref

cap:parameter.value: Strong Storm Causing Water To Move Onto Near Shore Ice Wednesday Night

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 1 at 4:37PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A strong storm moving north across the Bering Sea on Tuesday and Wednesday will bring water levels up 3 to 4 feet along the coast from the Bering Strait south on Wednesday and Thursday. This will cause water to move on top of the ice near the coast in some areas. This could cause trails that cross ice near the coast to become inundated. Ice could push onto the beach along south facing coast lines. This event will be similar what happened March 20, 2024.
Winter Storm Warnings, Watches and Advisories have been issued for most of these areas and are available on the Internet at weather.gov/afg.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Bering Strait Coast; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Eastern Norton Sound and Nulato Hills; Yukon Delta Coast; St Lawrence Island

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 1 at 3:34PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A strong cold front will bring snow squalls, blowing snow, and reduced visibility along with much colder temperatures to the Interior from Fairbanks and the Tanana Valley south to the Alaska Range tonight and Tuesday.
1 to 3 inches of snow is expected from Fairbanks south to the Alaska Range Monday night into Tuesday. Northwest winds gusting over 30 mph will cause low visibility in blowing snow, and snow drifts will form. Temperatures will fall into the single digits tonight and then below zero Tuesday night. Northwest winds and blowing snow will reach Fairbanks, Nenana and Denali this evening and continue into Tuesday morning. The northwest winds and blowing snow will reach Delta Junction, Tok and the Eastern Alaska Range later tonight and early Tuesday morning and continue through the day Tuesday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Upper Tanana Valley; Delta Junction; Upper Chena River Valley; Tanana Flats; Eielson AFB and Salcha; Goldstream Valley and Nenana Hills; Chatanika River Valley; Two Rivers; Fairbanks Metro Area; Nenana; Northern Denali Borough; Southern Denali Borough; Eastern Alaska Range North of Trims Camp; Eastern Alaska Range South of Trims Camp

cap:parameter.value: Strong Cold Front and Snow Squalls Expected Across the Interior Late This Evening and Tuesday

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 1 at 1:35PM EDT until April 6 at 9:00AM EDT by NWS Indianapolis IN
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Indianapolis IN has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Indiana...
Wabash River from Lafayette to Montezuma.
.Rainfall amounts of around two inches across much of central Indiana through Tuesday evening are expected to produce minor flooding along upper to middle parts of the Wabash basin. River flooding could begin by Tuesday afternoon at Lafayette and downstream locations thereafter. Locally higher rainfall amounts could produce more significant localized flooding. Persons with interests along area rivers should closely monitor the forecast as additional river flood warnings are possible further downstream on the Wabash as well as along other area rivers over the next couple of days.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Wabash River at Lafayette.
* WHEN...From Tuesday afternoon to late Saturday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Lowland flooding is in progress. Flood waters near SR 225 between Old SR 25 and Battleground. Warren CR 350 N near Black Rock Preserve and Tippecanoe CR 950 W in the Wabash Bottoms, Janssen Tract area may be impassable. Fort Ouiatenon grounds begin to flood. Flooding at the Grandville Public Access site.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 12:30 PM EDT Monday the stage was 4.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage early tomorrow afternoon to a crest of 15.7 feet Wednesday evening. It will then fall below flood stage late Friday evening. - Flood stage is 11.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Fountain, IN; Parke, IN; Tippecanoe, IN; Vermillion, IN; Warren, IN
